Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology Ministry of Education; National and Local Joint Engineering Laboratory of Energy Plant Biofuel Preparation and Utilization College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 PR China Linear α-olefins (LAOs) are high-value chemicals primarily derived from fossil-based resources. Therefore, the dehydration of biomass-derived fatty alcohols to produce LAOs has received widespread attention for its sustainability. However, achieving high selectivity for LAOs remains a significant challenge due to the higher thermodynamic stability of internal olefins. Additionally, there is still a lack of molecular-level understanding of the mechanism for the high-selectivity dehydration of long-chain fatty alcohols to produce LAOs. In this study, 1-decanol was selected as the model compound to investigate the dehydration process over a series of alkali metal oxides (K2O and Na2O) and alkaline earth metal oxides (BaO, CaO and MgO) modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Activity results showed that the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst achieved the highest α-decene selectivity (92.6 %) among all catalysts under mild reaction conditions. Characterization results illustrated that a small amount of loaded metal oxides had little impact on the texture properties of γ-Al2O3, but significantly altered its surface acid/base properties. In situ DRIFTS and control experiment results demonstrated that the bimolecular dehydration process involving the intermediate decyl ether was the dominant reaction pathway. DFT calculation results indicated that K2O modified γ-Al2O3 catalyst could lower the dissociation energy barrier of the hydroxyl group while raising the energy barrier of β-hydrogen migration compared to BaO and MgO modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts, thereby effectively inhibiting the isomerization of α-olefin into internal olefins. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key Words Fatty alcohol Linear α-olefin Dehydration γ-Al2O3 Alkali metal oxide Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Linear α-olefins (LAOs), with a terminal C=C bond in linear carbon chain (C8-C12), are significant organic feedstocks and intermediates, which are widely used as monomers for copolymer production as well as in the manufacture of polyolefins, surfactants, lubricants, plasticizers, and fine chemicals [1–4]. Currently, the main strategies for LAOs production are Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (F-T) and ethylene oligomerization. The former process uses iron or cobalt catalysts to convert syngas into α-olefins. Unfortunately, the selectivity of α-olefins is relatively low, and the high temperature and pressure conditions increase both capital and operational costs of the F-T process [5–7]. Meanwhile, both iron and cobalt catalysts always suffer from deactivation during reaction process due to the harsh reaction conditions [8,9]. For the ethylene oligomerization method, Ziegler-Natta catalysts are used to catalyze the polymerization of ethylene to produce LAOs with even carbon chain lengths [10–12]. However, controlling carbon chain growth to produce α-olefin with a specific and uniform chain length is quite challenging and the ethylene feedstock is primarily derived from fossil resources, which is an unsustainable method to manufacture LAOs [13,14]. Biomass, as a sustainable and renewable feedstock, has been used to prepare LAOs [15,16]. At present, this process mainly uses long-chain fatty acids and alcohols as feedstock [17]. Homogeneous catalysts such as Pd [18], Rh [19], Ir [20] and Ru [21] have been extensively studied for the fatty acids decarbonylative dehydration to produce LAOs. These methods employ ligands and a certain amount of sacrificial anhydride additives, combined with in situ distillation techniques to inhibit the formation of internal olefins. However, these noble-metal catalysts are difficult to recycle and reuse, making them economically unfeasible and far from meeting the industrial-scale requirements. Subsequently, Zhang et al. [22] used MoO x as a heterogeneous catalyst to perform the decarbonylative dehydration of fatty acids under solvent-free conditions, successfully achieving high α-olefin selectivity. However, the reaction still required stoichiometric amounts of acetic anhydride and phosphine ligands inevitably. Recent studies suggest that LAOs can be synthesized through the process of hydrogenating biomass-based fatty acids into fatty alcohols and then dehydrating fatty alcohols into LAOs [23]. As an alternative method, biomass-derived alcohol dehydration for the preparation of α-olefins has the advantages of high conversion and easy separation compared with fatty acids. Moreover, dehydration catalysts have been broadly studied for short-chain alcohols, such as the dehydration of ethanol to produce ethylene [24,25]. Among them, metal oxides are considered as promising catalysts [26–29], while Al2O3-based catalysts exhibit excellent performance in the catalytic preparation of α-olefins due to their porous structure and acid/base properties [30,31]. Ali et al. [32] prepared a physical mixture of nano-Al2O3 and ThO2 catalyst. When the mass ratio of Al2O3 and ThO2 was 6 : 1, 1-octadecanol was completely converted with a yield of 92 % for α-octadecene at 300 °C and 0.1 MPa N2. They believed that ThO2 hindered the isomerization and oligomerization of α-octadecene at high temperature, resulting in high α-olefin selectivity. Kim et al. [33] explored the effect of barium loaded on Al2O3 on the selectivity for α-octene. When the mass fraction of barium on the Ba/Al2O3 catalyst was 1.5 wt %, the highest conversion of 1-octanol was achieved with a selectivity of 85 % for 1-octene at 350 °C. The impregnated barium eliminated the strong Lewis acid sites, thereby inhibiting side reactions due to the re-adsorption of α-octene. Additionally, Chen et al. [34] developed a sodium-modified γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which could completely convert 1-decanol and achieve a high yield of α-decene under optimal reaction conditions. They believed that the modification with a small amount of sodium inhibited the strong acid sites and provided additional base sites, thus enhancing the selectivity of α-olefin. Although the high yield of LAOs has achieved from the dehydration of long-chain fatty alcohols, there are still some ambiguities among these investigated works. Firstly, although there have been reports on the modification of Al2O3 with alkali and alkaline earth metals separately for the production of α-olefins, the systematic studies are lacking in the current literature. Secondly, the mechanism of long-chain fatty alcohol dehydration, especially the formation of ether intermediate and the trade-offs between α-olefin and internal olefins, remains imprecise at the experimental level. In particular, the mechanism by which alkali metal modified γ-Al2O3 catalyst effectively hinders the formation of internal olefins has not been elucidated. In this work, we prepared a series of γ-Al2O3-based catalysts impregnated by alkali metal oxides (K2O and Na2O) and alkaline earth metal oxides (BaO, CaO and MgO) and investigated their catalytic performance and the mechanism for the conversion of 1-decanol to α-decene. Characterization results exhibited that γ-Al2O3 loaded with a small amount of alkali metal oxide (K2O) had relatively low Lewis acidity and high medium basicity without changing its intrinsic structure, achieving the highest α-decene selectivity (92.6 %). While on alkaline earth metal oxides modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts, 1-decanol dehydration primarily produced internal olefins. In situ DRIFTS results demonstrated that the conversion of 1-decanol to α-decene involved two sequential steps: first, the transformation of 1-decanol into decyl ether, followed by the conversion of decyl ether into α-decene. DFT calculation results revealed that the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had the lowest dissociation energy barrier of hydroxyl group and the highest β-hydrogen transfer energy barrier, which effectively suppressed the formation of internal olefins, thereby exhibiting high α-olefin selectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials γ-Al2O3 was purchased from Nanjing Xianfeng Nanotechnology Company, China. Analytical grade KNO3, NaNO3, Ba(NO3)2, Ca(NO3)2·4H2O and Mg(NO3)2·6H2O were purchased from Chengdu Cologne Chemical Company, China and other reagents including 1-decanol (99 %), α-decene (99 %) and n-decyl ether (95 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Company, China. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were synthesized using the incipient-wetness impregnation method. Typically, 0.001 mol of KNO3 was dissolved in 46.2 mL deionized water, the resulting solution was slowly added to 10 g of the γ-Al2O3 (γ-Al2O3 was pretreated at 500 °C for 4 h before impregnation). The mixture was stirred uniformly and then left to stand for 12 h. Subsequently, the sample was evaporated in an oil bath at 80 °C and placed in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h. After drying, the sample was ground into fine powder and calcined at 600 °C in static air for 4 h. The resulting sample was denoted as K2O/γ-Al2O3. The preparation procedure of Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was the same as that of K2O/γ-Al2O3, and NaNO3, Ba(NO3)2, Ca(NO3)2·4H2O and Mg(NO3)2·6H2O were used as the source of metal, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was obtained using a Shimazu XRD-6100 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 30 mA. The scanning angle and speed were 30 – 80 ° and 5 ° min-1, respectively. The XRD patterns were used to analyze the crystal phase structure of the catalysts by Jade 9 software. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 analyzer. The samples were degassed under vacuum at 120 °C for 2 h and then heated to 300 °C for 2 h before testing. The specific surface area was obtained by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, and the average pore size and volume were obtained by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) was performed on a BRUKER VERTEX 70 FT-IR spectrometer. A certain amount of sample was pretreated at 300 °C under vacuum for 1 h and then the background spectra were recorded during the cooling process. After adsorbing pyridine for 30 min at room temperature, the desorption spectra were obtained. All spectra were recorded at 4 cm-1 resolution with 16 co-added scans. CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was performed at Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. Approximately 0.1 g of sample was pretreated by heating to 300 °C under high-purity He gas flow (25 mL min-1) for 1 h and then cooling to 50 °C. CO2-He mixture (10 % CO2/He) was used to substitute He gas flow, where the CO2 adsorption was performed at 50 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the sample was purged with He gas flow for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed CO2 on the surface, and then heated to 500 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the He gas flow for CO2 desorption. The desorbed CO2 was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to obtain the desorption curve and the amount of base was calculated using the calibration file obtained by a quantitative loop. In situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) was performed using the same instrument as Py-IR experiments. Firstly, the catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h to remove impurities physically adsorbed on the surface and the background spectra were recorded during the cooling process. After the temperature was lowered to room temperature, 1-decanol was dropped on the surface of the catalyst for 30 min, and then the catalyst was heated to 300 °C to obtain the spectra (directly collected without remaining at every temperature point). The whole process was conducted in a nitrogen flow (100 mL min-1) and all spectra were recorded at 4 cm-1 resolution with 16 co-added scans. 2.4 Computational methods All spin-polarized calculations were conducted using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [35] with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [36]. The electron interactions were treated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [37]. A cutoff of 400 eV was selected for the plane-wave basis set. In the calculation models, a supercell of γ-Al2O3 (001) was constructed, comprising 64 Al and 96 O atoms [38,39]. A vacuum layer of 15 Å was employed to eliminate periodic interactions. During the optimization calculations, the bottom four layers were fixed, while the top three layers were allowed to relax to their equilibrium positions. The Brillouin zone was sampled with a gamma-centered 2 × 2 × 1 k-point for all calculations. The convergence energy threshold was set to 10⁻5 eV, and the force on each atom was required to be within 0.02 eV/Å. The adsorption energy (E ads) was calculated using the following equation: (1) E a d s = E x / s l a b − E s l a b − E x where E x/slab represents the energy of the slab with adsorbates, E slab denotes the energy of the bare slab, and E x signifies the energy of the adsorbate in the free phase. Reaction energies (ΔE) were defined as (2) Δ E = E F S − E I S where EFS and EIS represents the final state energy and initial state energy, respectively. The reaction barrier (E a) was calculated using the following equation: (3) E a = E T S − E I S where ETS is the energy of the transition state and EIS is the energy of the initial state. All transition states were calculated using the climbing image nudged elastic band method (CI-NEB), [40] with the stretching frequencies analyzed to ascertain whether a stationary point is a minimum state with only one imaginary frequency. 2.5 Activity test and product analysis The conversion of 1-decanol was performed in a fixed-bed reactor (The diameter and length of fixed-bed reactor were 13 mm and 500 mm, respectively, and the constant temperature zone was 120 mm). The lower layer of the reaction tube was filled with 32 g of inert silicate filler and 3 g of catalyst (crushed and sieved to 20–40 mesh before the experiment) and 12 g of silicate filler were mixed to fill the upper layer. The catalyst was heated to 300 °C at a rate of 5 °C min-1 in a nitrogen flow (GHSV= 1400 h-1) at ambient pressure and then 1-decanol was injected into the reactor (LHSV= 0.3 h-1). After 5 h of reaction, the reaction system was cooled down and the product was collected. All the products were dehydrated by anhydrous CaCl2 for analysis and product yield calculation. The activity tests of all catalysts were repeated three times. The stability test of the catalyst was conducted under the same reaction conditions as the activity test for 10 runs and the catalyst was not regenerated or purified after each run. Liquid product was quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (Panna A91) with a TCD detector. A HP-5 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) was used to separate the products and the injection port and detector temperature are 280 °C. Tetradecane was chosen as the internal standard for the quantitative analysis. The conversion of 1-decanol and the yield and selectivity of α-denece were calculated by the following equation: (4) Conv ersi on ( % ) = ( W 1 − deca nol , inje cted − W 1 − deca nol , coll ected ) / W 1 − deca nol , inje cted × 100 % (5) Yield ( % ) = ( W α − dece ne , coll ected / W 1 − deca nol , inje cted ) × 100 % (6) Sele ctiv ity ( % ) = ( W α − dece ne , coll ected / W prod ucts , coll ected ) × 100 % where W represents the weight of the substance. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1 shows the catalytic activity of K2O/γ-Al2O3, Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The results illustrated that all catalysts could fully convert 1-decanol under ambient pressure at 300 °C. Among them, the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited an outstanding performance compared to other catalysts in Fig. 1 (a), achieving an α-decene selectivity of 92.6 %, while the Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts showed decreasing selectivity for α-decene (89.3 %, 76.7 %, 55.6 %, 12.6 % and 7.7 %, respectively). In addition to α-decene, we also detected the formation of internal decenes, including 2-decene, 3-decene and 5-decene, as shown in Fig. 1 (b). The activity results suggested that a small amount of K2O and Na2O played an important role in the selective conversion of 1-decanol into α-decene, whereas BaO, CaO and MgO impregnated on γ-Al2O3 had a tendency to produce more internal decenes. To systematically evaluate the effect of K₂O loading on catalytic performance, we tested both higher (0.01 mol) and lower (0.0005 mol) loadings. As demonstrated in Fig. S1, the catalyst with 0.001 mol K2O exhibited superior activity and α-decene selectivity compared to other loadings, confirming 0.001 mol as the optimal loading amount. Considering the excellent catalytic activity of the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, we conducted the stability test as shown in Fig. 1 (c). The experimental results showed that after a long-term reaction time of 50 h, the conversion of 1-decanol and the selectivity of α-decene maintained above 91.4 % and 88.0 %, respectively, demonstrating that the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst possessed great stability. 3.2 Catalyst characterizations The structural information of K2O/γ-Al2O3, Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts was characterized by XRD and BET, as shown in Fig. 2 . For the catalysts, the diffraction peaks were observed at 37.5 °, 39.3 °, 45.8 °, 60.7 ° and 67.0 °, which were the characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 00–050–0741) (Fig. 2 (a)). Additionally, the characteristic diffraction peaks of K2O, Na2O, BaO, CaO and MgO were not observed and the main peak at 67.0 ° for all catalysts did not shift compared to the main peak of γ-Al2O3, as shown in Fig. 2 (b), indicating that the loaded alkali and alkaline earth metal oxides were highly dispersed on the γ-Al2O3. In Fig. 2 (c), all samples displayed Ⅳ-type adsorption isotherms with distinct H2-type hysteresis loops, and the ratio of P/P0 ranged from 0.6 to 1.0, proving that they were mesoporous materials. Moreover, the pore size distribution of the samples was primarily around 11 nm, further confirming their mesoporous property (Fig. S2). Table 1 lists the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, where the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had the largest surface area (184.0 m2 g-1), and the surface area of Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ- Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts were 182.1, 178.0, 177.4, 170.3 and 171.2 m2 g-1, respectively. These results suggested that K2O, Na2O, BaO, CaO and MgO had little effect on the texture properties of γ-Al2O3. The surface acid/base properties of K2O/γ-Al2O3, Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts were investigated by Py-IR and CO2-TPD experiments in Fig. 3 , respectively. In the Py-IR experiments shown in Fig. 3 (a), all catalysts exhibited similar acid distribution compared to the γ-Al2O3. The bands around 1445 cm-1 (including the shoulder band at 1452 cm-1), 1576 cm-1, 1612 cm-1 were attributed to Lewis acid sites (LAS) [41–43]. The band at 1490 cm−1 was also attributed to LAS due to the absence of Brønsted acid site (BAS) [34]. The band at 1594 cm-1 was attributed to the hydrogen band for the combination of pyridine and the hydroxyl group on the surface of γ-Al2O3 [44]. These results demonstrated that there were only LAS on the surface of γ-Al2O3-based catalysts. Furthermore, the acid amount of catalysts was calculated by the integration of LAS band around 1445 cm-1 [45]. As displayed in Table 1, the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had the least Lewis acid amount (0.049 mmol g-1) among all catalysts. The Lewis acid amount of Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts were 0.103, 0.131, 0.136, 0.158 and 0.208 mmol g-1, respectively. For the base properties of catalysts measured by CO2-TPD in Fig. 3 (b), the base sites were classified into two types according to the CO2 desorption temperature. The peak between 50 and 300 °C was assigned to the weak base site derived from the surface hydroxyl group of γ-Al2O3 [46,47] and the peak between 300 and 500 °C was attributed to the medium base site caused by the impregnation of K2O, Na2O, BaO, CaO and MgO [48,49]. The corresponding base amount is listed in Table 1. The weak base amount of K2O/γ-Al2O3, Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3, MgO/γ-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts was 0.058, 0.089, 0.093, 0.095, 0.097 and 0.346 mmol g-1, respectively, while the medium base amount was 0.030, 0.013, 0.011, 0.010, 0.009 and 0.097 mmol g-1, respectively. As the alkalinity of the impregnated metal oxides increased, the amount of weak base site decreased, while the amount of medium base site increased. This indicated that the impregnated metal oxides interacted with the surface of γ-Al2O3, resulting in the formation of M-O-Al bonds [50]. The impregnation of alkali and alkaline earth metal oxides altered the surface acid/base properties of γ-Al2O3. Combined with the catalytic activity results, it could be inferred that the selectivity of α-decene was closely related to the amount of Lewis acid and medium base. The highest selectivity of α-decene was achieved on the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst when Lewis acid amount was the lowest and the medium basic amount was the highest compared with other metal oxide loaded catalysts. In contrast, higher Lewis acid amount and lower medium base amount would lead to lower selectivity of α-decene. Based on the above results and reported works [51], it could be concluded the acid/base sites played a synergistic role in the conversion of 1-decanol, and the loading alkali metal oxides weakened the acidity of γ-Al2O3, preventing olefin isomerization, thus resulting in the high selectivity of α-olefin. 3.3 Reaction mechanism In order to gain insight into the mechanism of 1-decanol conversion into α-decene, in situ DRIFTS measurements were carried out on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. For simulating the reaction environment, 1-decanol was dropped onto the catalyst surface under the nitrogen atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the bands at 2963, 2924, and 2856 cm-1 were assigned to the CHx stretching vibration of 1-decanol [52]. When the temperature was raised to 150 °C, a new band appeared at 2734 cm-1, which was ascribed to the vibrational band of C-O-C in decyl ether [53]. Moreover, this band was observed in the in situ DRIFTS spectra of all catalysts (seen in Fig. 4 (b), Fig. 4 (c) and Fig. S3), thus it could be speculated that the dehydration process of 1-decanol was similar on γ-Al2O3-based catalysts, which involved the generation of decyl ether as intermediate product. For further investigation of the mechanism of decyl ether conversion into decene, decyl ether was dropped onto the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst under the identical experimental conditions. Surprisingly, the intensity of the band at 2734 cm-1 significantly weakened at 230 °C, and a new band appeared at 1668 cm-1 (shown in Fig. 4 (d)), which was attributed to the C=C stretching vibration [54], indicating that decyl ether was ultimately transformed into decene. We also conducted in situ DRIFTS experiment for α-decene absorption on the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which confirmed that the band at 1668 cm-1 (shown in Fig. S4) was corresponded to the C=C stretching vibration. To further confirm the intermediate product in this reaction, the control experiments of the conversion of 1-decanol were carried out on the K2O/γ- Al2O3 catalyst. To lower the conversion of the reaction, LHSV was increased by 10 times and 20 times, respectively. The decyl ether was evidently detected in the reaction products according to the GC spectra and activity performance, as displayed in Fig. S5, which was consistent with the in situ DRIFTS results. Therefore, the results above implied that the generation of decene involved bimolecular dehydration of 1-decanol with decyl ether as an intermediate on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. To further demonstrate the reaction mechanism on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, we performed DFT calculations. For the sake of convenience in calculation, the dehydration of 1-butanol to form butane was chosen as the probe reaction and the adsorption configurations of intermediates on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were shown in Fig. S6-S8. The energy profile of bimolecular dehydration of 1-butanol to form butyl ether was displayed in Fig. S9. The energy barriers on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, and MgO/γ-Al2O3 were 0.27 eV, 0.46 eV, and 0.39 eV, respectively. These results indicated that the bimolecular dehydration pathway was more favorable on the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Since the reaction mechanism of 1-decanol dehydration was the same on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, but the activity results showed significant selectivity difference for α-decene. The highest α-decene selectivity was obtained on the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst while BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts preferred to produce more internal decenes. Therefore, DFT calculations on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were performed to uncover the isomerization process of α-decene, the adsorption configurations of intermediates on K2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were also shown in Fig. S6-S8. The potential energy profile was shown in Fig. 5 . The energy barrier on the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for removing the hydroxyl group from 1-butanol was 0.85 eV, and the heat released was 1.87 eV. Subsequently, the energy barrier for the removal of the β-hydrogen was 2.66 eV, and the energy barriers for intramolecular hydrogen migration were 3.23 eV and 1.68 eV, respectively. On the BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 surfaces, the energy barriers for hydroxyl removal from 1-butanol were 1.51 eV and 1.14 eV, respectively, and the barriers for dehydrogenation to form butene were 1.13 eV and 1.55 eV, respectively. For BaO/γ-Al2O3, the energy barriers for intramolecular hydrogen migration were 2.80 eV and 2.04 eV, while for MgO/γ-Al2O3, the energy barriers for intramolecular hydrogen migration were 2.01 eV and 2.38 eV, respectively. Therefore, we could conclude that the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst not only facilitated the dissociation of the hydroxyl group but also hindered the migration of the β-hydrogen, which made the product remain at α-olefin rather than internal olefins. While BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts could also completely convert 1-decanol to decene at a relatively high temperature, however, they were more inclined to produce internal decenes due to the lower energy barrier required for β-hydrogen migration, resulting in a lower selectivity for α-decene. Based on the above results, we propose the possible reaction mechanism for the preparation of α-decene from 1-decanol on alkali and alkaline earth metal oxides modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6 . The dehydration of 1-decanol was divided into two pathways: bimolecular and unimolecular dehydration [55], respectively. According to the generation of decyl ether from the in situ DRIFTS experiments and control experiments (Fig. 4 and Fig. S4), it was supposed that bimolecular dehydration was the dominant reaction pathway. Through the synergistic effect of acid/base sites on the catalyst, the hydroxyl group of the long-chain fatty alcohol adsorbed on the acid site, while the β-hydrogen interacted with the base site. This interaction facilitated the formation of decyl ether via bimolecular dehydration, which subsequently underwent further dehydration to produce decene. For alkali metal oxide (K2O, Na2O) modified γ-Al2O3, the acidity was weakened according to the Py-IR results (Fig. 3), thus the C=C double-bond was difficult to shift and remained at the terminal to form α-decene. Based on the DFT calculation results, the α-olefin remained non-isomerization into internal olefins because the energy barrier for β-hydrogen migration was too high on the alkali metal oxide (K2O) modified γ-Al2O3. However, for BaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the generated α-olefin isomerized to internal olefins due to the low energy barrier for β-hydrogen migration. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have reported alkali metal oxides modified γ-Al2O3 for highly selective preparation of α-decene from 1-decanol compared to alkaline earth metal oxides modified γ-Al2O3. The alkali metal oxides (K2O and Na2O) could decrease the acidity of γ-Al2O3, and the acid/base sites played a synergistic role in the conversion of 1-decanol. The dehydration pathways of long-chain fatty alcohol on K2O/γ-Al2O3, Na2O/γ-Al2O3, BaO/γ-Al2O3, CaO/γ-Al2O3 and MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were identical, proceeding via bimolecular dehydration. The impregnation of alkali metal oxide (K2O) on γ-Al2O3 also increased the energy barrier for β-hydrogen migration, leading to the C=C double-bond remaining at the terminal position, thereby achieving the high selectivity for α-olefin. While alkaline earth metal oxides (BaO and MgO) were impregnated, the energy barriers for β-hydrogen migration were lower, which ultimately lead to the generation of a large amount of internal olefins. Therefore, alkali metal oxide modified γ-Al2O3 exhibited superior selectivity for α-decene in the conversion of fatty alcohol, outperforming γ-Al2O3 modified with alkaline earth metal oxides. This work revealed the essence of achieving high selectivity for α-olefin in the dehydration of long-chain fatty alcohol catalyzed by the alkali metal oxides modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts, and also provided a reliable method for green production of α-olefin. coredata.dc:description: Linear α-olefins (LAOs) are high-value chemicals primarily derived from fossil-based resources. Therefore, the dehydration of biomass-derived fatty alcohols to produce LAOs has received widespread attention for its sustainability. However, achieving high selectivity for LAOs remains a significant challenge due to the higher thermodynamic stability of internal olefins. Additionally, there is still a lack of molecular-level understanding of the mechanism for the high-selectivity dehydration of long-chain fatty alcohols to produce LAOs. In this study, 1-decanol was selected as the model compound to investigate the dehydration process over a series of alkali metal oxides (K2O and Na2O) and alkaline earth metal oxides (BaO, CaO and MgO) modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Activity results showed that the K2O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst achieved the highest α-decene selectivity (92.6 %) among all catalysts under mild reaction conditions. Characterization results illustrated that a small amount of loaded metal oxides had little impact on the texture properties of γ-Al2O3, but significantly altered its surface acid/base properties. In situ DRIFTS and control experiment results demonstrated that the bimolecular dehydration process involving the intermediate decyl ether was the dominant reaction pathway. DFT calculation results indicated that K2O modified γ-Al2O3 catalyst could lower the dissociation energy barrier of the hydroxyl group while raising the energy barrier of β-hydrogen migration compared to BaO and MgO modified γ-Al2O3 catalysts, thereby effectively inhibiting the isomerization of α-olefin into internal olefins.
